nodes.bodyText: Can you rename this variable so it can be consistent with other naming (I see three naming, enclosingUnionMember, UnionMember, unionDataMember)

enclosingUnionMember name is specifically in the context of traversing schemas. Here to provide some context of schema, I think calling it "unionMember" makes more sense rather than "enclosingUnionMember".
I will update unionDataMember to unionMember.
Same here, there are two paths in context, you can rename it to pathSpecToSchema

In the AnnotationCheckContext, I used String[] _pathToSchema. The reason why I convert pathSpec to String[] paths, because CompatibilityMessage requires String[] paths as input, I do not want users to convert it, which is unnecessary.
I feel pathToSchema makes more sense here, because it is not PathSpec.

I think a better solution would be to update CompatibiliyMessage to accept PathSpec and convert to array if needed.
Then you can re-use the PathSpec in the map key below and avoid creating a new array for every node.
@nickibi CompatibilityMessage's path is not well defined (it could be anything, as long as a string array). Here you seems to be really storing the pathspec in the annotationCheckContext
Add a new constructor for CompatibiliyMessage to accept PathSpec.
If we make it default method, that means every handler will return a AnnotationCompatibilityResult. Is there a way to tell whether or not this check happened? How can we distinguish the two cases

How does the handler handle these Else branch cases?  Maybe add some brief comments
Updated the comments and also added logic to handle else branch cases.
similarly, perhaps add some comments here
added comments
Add log before throwing exception
log and throw exception is anti-pattern, right ? https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6639963/why-is-log-and-throw-considered-an-anti-pattern
Added log
not throwing exception
same, not throwing exception

The logic is still similar to ValidateSchemaAnnotationTask, do you think we can extract the common part to not repeat yourself? Later if we change the enforcement of expected number of hanlders per module, we don't need to change on two places
You are right, I will move this part to the SchemaAnnotationHandlerUtil.

I will recommend to use longer name here, --handlerJarPath and handlerClassName. We don't need to be concise for this particular use case, but need to be explicit (for example later do a code search would be easier)
fixed
These code is still a lot similar to SchemaAnnotationValidatorCmdLineApp, should DRY
Yes, moved this one to a util class which can be used by both 'SchemaAnnotationValidatorCmdLineApp' and 'PegasusSchemaSnapshotCompatibilityChecker'.

Can you also post example error message to this PR ? like your local test?
Otherwise I was expecting to see it from some unit test.

[checker] [RS-COMPAT]: true
[checker] [MD-COMPAT]: true
[checker] [SCHEMA-ANNOTATION-COMPAT]: false

Just a thought: Unlike other message, Annotation incompatible  message doesn't have a message placeholder and description, which actually made it more difficult to be code-searched

nodes.bodyText: I didn't understand why there is any other error message for annotation other than ANNOTATION_INCOMPATIBLE_CHANGE ?

Since we do not provide annotation compatibility rules, customers provide the way how they want to check the annotations. There are some common sense rules like - change breaks new reader, change breaks old reader or change breaks new and old reader. The ANNOTATION_INCOMPATIBLE_CHANGE provide an option to users to define the way how they want to define the compatibility other than above. We provide the framework to support it.
then do you think CUSTOM_ANNOTATION_INCOMPATIBLE_CHANGE will be a better definition?
Discussed offline, we will only have ANNOTATION_INCOMPATIBLE_CHANGE  here.

I prefer method names to start with a verb: doSomething..
So rename this to "checkCompatibility" ? "annotation" is implied by context.
Space between String, Object

nodes.bodyText: Add javadoc on these methods.
Removed this method, because add a method to indicate implement compatibility check on the handler.
remove extra line
It looks like the only way to add messages is by doing getMessages().add(..). It feels odd, why not add a method "addMessage(...)" to this class?
Add a  addMessage() method.

Sorry for late review,
A consideration for this function is to make it readable, and reusable.
Would it be possible if we can use some string formatted json to represent the all the datamap or properties.
And use something like DataMapUtil's function to read those json formated string to dataMap objects?
Discussed offline, update the test cases in a cleaner way.
Maybe document on why?
Why in terms of not execute the callback on POST_ORDER

In the DataSchemaRichContextTraverser, the schemaVisitor.callbackOnContext are triggered twice by default. First is PRE_ORDER, then is POST_ORDER.
For the usecase here, we only need to get the schema context of each node, traversing once is enough. Therefore, when it's POST_ORDER, we skip it.
Added comments.
style convention?
fixed
Maybe we can move this statement that generates the annotationContextAndResolvedProperties object into the next line where it is the only place that it is being used?
Fixed
This function name seems confusing, in the comment it is meant for annotation check not the schema itself
Please don't increase the length of checkPegasusSchemaCompatibility into checkPegasusSchemaAnnoationaCompatibility
Change name to 'checkPegasusSchemaAnnotation'. Later on I will add new method 'checkExtensionSchemaAnnotation' for extension annotation check.

Maybe we can have a new interface that specifically deals compatibility check.
My reason being the action to check compatibility maybe not needed for every schema annotation handler, so we create a new interface the inherit schema annotation handler, to add some more specific functions to schema annotation handler.
That way, you don't worry about using default here, and leave original schemaAnnotationHandler some flexibility.

nodes.bodyText:
We had such discussion during the design phase. The main idea to put it into the SchemaAnnotationHandler is to complete the features of Schema Annotation Processor. In the handler, users provide how to resolve a custom annotation, how to validate a custom annotation. The compatibility check part was missing.
Also it would provide better developer experience to users, they just need to have one SchemaAnnotationHandler config.
More details can be found in the design doc.

nodes.bodyText: also check if the value is true?
Nevermind, I was not sure how "hasOption" worked.
Quit the checker if there is an error.
fixed.
I don't think you need this flag, just use !_handlers.isEmpty() when needed.
Updated.
Instead of doing this separately, just add the handler for extension annotation to the _handlers list.

Actually, I am thinking about using a different method in AnnotationCompatibilityChecker for extension schema check.
the extension schema does not require the annotation processor to process the schema, there is no property resolve/override requirements for extension schemas. We just need a SchemaHandler which provides the compatibility check logic for extension schema. Also we need a schema visitor to get pathSpec and properties. It will traverse the schema once, which reduces the unnecessary schema traverse(process annotation).

I don't understand how it would be better. You are going to create another branch for extensions which does the. same thing as the annotation checker.
If you have only the extension annotation handler, its visitor would traverse the schema once and get you the same result, right? The path override based traversal will happen only if handlers for annotations that support such overrides are present.

Discussed offline.
I introduced a new schema visitor - IdentitySchemaVisitor, which will not traverse the schema. It can be used for extension schema annotation check or other use cases which do not need override properties but would like to do the compatibility check. There will be no extra/unnecessary schema traverse for such case.
Now all the annotation check use cases will fall into the same path: go to annotation processor to process the annotation, then do the annotation compatibility check.
Include the original exception e in the new exception.
Updated
The first line is redundant. Document that this is a utility class to help with annotation compatibility checking.
fixed

link to the method in annotation handler.
I think there is some repetition in this doc. Can you simplify it?
compatibilities -> compatibility

process -> Process
olderSchema -> prevSchema
newerSchema -> currentSchema
(to keep the naming consistent everywhere)
remove if you are not adding any documentation.
just use e.getValue() to avoid a map lookup.

This logic feels odd. Did you consider adding a method on the handler directly?
eg, boolean implementsCompatibilityChecking()
add a method on the handler instead.

or the field was deleted.
The logic here would be simple if you returned the empty resolveProperties instead if removing it (in AnnotationCheckResolvedPropertiesVisitor)
So the only case to handle is deleted field. At this point, does it make sense to do annotation compatibility checking? Would the schema compatibility checking be enough?

Yes, I agree.
I will return empty resolvedProperties in AnnotationCheckResolvedPropertiesVistor.
Then, we do not need this else branch check at all.
I think we should provide such check to the annotation check, if an existing field is removed. Users should decide whether they will do something or not.
this duplication can be avoided if we added a method on the handler to check.
add a method on the handler.
either because newer schema aded new annotations or added new field with annotations
Updated the logic here.

How would the compatibility checker differentiate between a new field(compatible) vs adding new annotations(may not be compatible)?
I think we should invoke the checker only for new annotations. And for new fields skip annotation checking?
Or, send empty context/map for the case where new annotations were added. and use null when a new field was added.

Once we return empty resolvedProperties in AnnotationCheckResolvedPropertiesVistor. We would figure out adding new annotation on an existing field use case. Older schema and newer schema will have the same path specs. It will be handled in the previous check.
For this branch, only new field with new annotation use case will fall in to this check.
My question is for new field with new annotation case, do we need to do the compatibility check?
My intuition says we can ignore the new field with new annotation case. Confirm with @junchuanwang as he has better context on annotations.
Discussed offline with @nickibi, I recommend to add this check for new field with new annotation
Add check for new field with new annotation case.
Leave the empty resolvedProperties for fields without any annotation. It would simplify the compatibility checking logic.

Yes, that's right.
Updated.
add extra newline between methods.

You could refactor this logic to a utility method:
chooseProperties(preferredProperties, fallbackProperties)
Updated to use a utility method.

Reword the doc to not be specific about compatibility check.
This is a visitor to use when override is not needed. compatibility is one such usecase.

+package com.linkedin.data.schema.annotation;
+
+
+import com.linkedin.data.schema.DataSchema;
+import com.linkedin.data.schema.DataSchemaTraverse;
+
+
+/**
+ * This SchemaVisitor is used to not traverse the data schema.
+ * Users may want to use Schema Annotation Processor framework to do annotation compatibility check,
+ * but they do need to override the annotations, they can use this visitor in the handler to skip annotation overriding.
+ *
+ * @author Yingjie Bi
+ */
+public class IdentitySchemaVisitor implements SchemaVisitor
+{
+
+  @Override
+  public void callbackOnContext(TraverserContext context, DataSchemaTraverse.Order order) {
+    // skip post order traverse
+    if (order == DataSchemaTraverse.Order.POST_ORDER)
+    {
+      return;
+    }
+
+    if (context.getParentSchema() == null)

+  /**
+   * This method is used to indicate whether the schema annotation handler implement the checkCompatibility method.
+   * @return false by default. Users could override this method to return true, if they implement the checkCompatibility method.
+   */
+  default boolean implementCheckCompatibility()

This is odd, you shouldn't use static variables to store state. See my comment below

Don't do this. Instead have the actual implementation in this method, based on the input arg. The other method should call this with "false" for skipValidateProcessResult.
nit: I personally prefer not to use negative for boolean params. So suggest using validateProcessResult as the arg and switch the condiation.

I just realized this wouldn't work if there are multiple handlers. When the first handler is processed, it would remove all pathSpecs from the resolved properties map.
Good catch. I updated to use a copyResolvedPropertiesMap for each handler instead.

This might be a problem for large schemas. Did you consider reversing the loops?
remove handlers that don't implement compatibility

foreach entry in prevResolvedProperties:
  foreach hander:
     check(entry)
     remove path from currProperties
foreach entry in currProperties
   foreach handler:
      check(entry)
